definition: (variant of 真相[zhen1 xiang4]) the truth about sth/the actual facts

sentences.english: They don't really look like white elephants.
sentences.chinese: 看上去並不真象一羣白象。

sentences.english: You speak like a man of spirit .
sentences.chinese: 你說的話真象個大丈夫。

sentences.english: Mon Dieu! it is like a little republic.
sentences.chinese: 那真象一個小小的共和國。

sentences.english: The detective tried to ascertain the facts about the robbery.
sentences.chinese: 這個偵察員力圖弄清這一盜竊案的事實真象。

sentences.english: When I photograph, what I am really doing is seeking answers to things.
sentences.chinese: 當我攝影時，實際上我正在尋求事物的真象。

sentences.english: We can evolve the truth from a mass of confused evidence.
sentences.chinese: 我們可以從複雜的證據中推斷事實真象。

sentences.english: Why should they not go on to Scotland, if that had been the case?
sentences.chinese: 要是真象你所想的那樣，那他們幹嗎不到蘇格蘭去呢？

sentences.english: going to tell you the true story now.
sentences.chinese: 現在我將告訴你們事情的真象。

sentences.english: So Einstein thought this book "easily understandable" ?
sentences.chinese: 真象愛因斯坦所認爲的那樣“易解”？

sentences.english: The mammoth, a ancient elephant, mammalia, long nose item, real elephant faculty.
sentences.chinese: 猛獁象，古脊椎動物，哺乳綱，長鼻目，真象科。

sentences.english: Recieiving this award is just like a dream come true .
sentences.chinese: 得到這個獎項真象是夢想成真。

definition: trying to hide it makes it more conspicuous (idiom); A cover up only makes matters worse.
absolutely true (idiom)/manifold/true from many points of view
to confess without being pressed/to make a confession without duress
to look exactly like/to be the spitting image of
to speak forcefully and with justice (idiom); to argue with the courage of one's convictions/also written 振振有詞|振振有词
mirror (as a metaphor for sth beautiful, bright and flat -- such as a lake -- or sth that provides clarity and insight)
to feel guilty as a thief (idiom); to have sth on one's conscience
